isis.stitle: TSI 02–12–09 - Release of New Fractured Connecting Rod Assembly

subjectgroup.subject: Release of New Fractured Connecting Rod Assembly

caution.para: To avoid engine damage when servicing, do not mix old tongue and groove connecting rods with new fractured connecting rods in the same engine. The weights of the connecting rods are different and will cause engine vibration if mixed.

The old tongue and groove connecting rod will still be available for servicing individual power cylinders that predate the change. The new fractured connecting rods can be used in engines with S/N 1194039 — 1363043 only if a complete set of six new rods is installed.

Keep the fractured mating surfaces clean and free of lint and debris. Do not allow the mating surfaces to rest on any surface. Do not bump the mating surfaces or drop the connecting rod or cap. This could cause chipping and wear on the mating surface, resulting in improper mating during installation and possible engine damage.

geninfo.para: A new fractured connecting rod assembly (1841615C91) has been implemented into production engines (S/N 1363044 and up) to replace the tongue and groove connecting rod assembly (1830153C91). The new assembly consists of the connecting rod, cap and two bolts.

The fractured connecting rod joint provides better mating between the rod and the cap than the current tongue and groove machined joint. The new connecting rod bushing has a larger outside diameter than the old bushing to accommodate a larger wall thickness. The inside diameter has also been increased slightly to increase piston pin rotation.

note.para: Do not use the service bolts for old tongue and groove connecting rods with the new fractured connecting rods.

svcproc.title: Special Features

caution.para: If the rod cap is reversed when assembled to the connecting rod or a rod cap is not installed on its original matching connecting rod, the fractured mating surfaces will be ruined. This may cause the rod cap to come loose and cause engine damage. The entire connecting rod must be replaced.

svcproc.para: The fractured mating surfaces of each rod and cap pair are precisely matched. Always keep each cap with its respective rod. If unsure, match the serial numbers on the sides of each rod and cap.

figure.caption: Figure 2. Offset for Incorrect Rod Cap Assembly

svcproc.para: The rod cap can only be correctly installed on the connecting rod if it is oriented in the correct direction. If the rod cap is reversed during assembly of the connecting rod, an obvious offset will be seen at the mating surfaces. If the connecting rod assembly is installed on the crankshaft in this manner, the connecting rod must be replaced. Also check the crankpin fillets for damage. Such damage will require replacement of the crankshaft.
Each rod cap has an arrow for correct orientation in the engine during installation. The arrow must point toward the front of the engine.

svcproc.title: Separating the Cap From a Fractured Connecting Rod

svcprocinfo.para: Use the following special procedures to avoid damaging the mating surfaces.

figure.caption: Figure 4. Removing the Connecting Rod Cap from the Engine

step1.para: Loosen both connecting rod bolts two turns.
Use a brass hammer to tap on the bolt heads until the cap comes loose from the connecting rod.
Remove the bolts and the cap.
If the cap can be pulled away from the connecting rod, proceed with the assembly procedure in the service manual.
If the cap cannot be pulled away from the connecting rod, place the connecting rod on a work bench with the cap extending over the edge of the work bench.
Grasp the connecting rod with one hand and the cap with the other. Press down on the cap to bend it away from the connecting rod.
